title: Putin sorry for Lavrov's claim Hitler was part Jewish - Israel PM
description: Russia's foreign minister claimed that Nazi leader Adolf Hitler had Jewish blood, sparking outrage.

title: Ukraine war has dragged on, admits Putin ally Lukashenko
description: Belarus's authoritarian leader Lukashenko has defended the war but wants it to end.

title: Donbas fighting: Risking capture to evacuate the vulnerable from the front line
description: Civilian volunteers are going to the front line, but some have been detained by Russian forces.

title: Covid: World’s true pandemic death toll nearly 15 million, says WHO
description: These include deaths from Covid and from the indirect effects of the pandemic over two years worldwide.

title: China building collapse: Woman rescued from rubble after six days
description: The collapse of a building in the city of Changsha is now known to have killed at least 26 people.

title: Kenya alarm after carrier bag mistaken for stray lion
description: The Kenyan villagers were on alert after some of their livestock had recently gone missing.

title: Elon Musk lines up $7bn backing for Twitter deal
description: The billionaire has tapped the likes of Oracle's Larry Ellison and Sequoia to finance the takeover.

title: Iraq dust storm leaves 5,000 people needing treatment
description: It is the seventh severe dust storm in weeks, turning skies orange and causing breathing problems.

title: Senegal midwives go on trial in Louga over Astou Sokhna's death
description: Astou Sokhna died after reportedly being refused a Caesarean, sparking a national outcry.

title: Turkey's cost of living soars nearly 70%
description: Everyday goods including food and transport costs have seen among the biggest annual increases.

title: Why 9 May Victory Day is so important for Russia
description: Vladimir Putin has made it an annual event, but amid war in Ukraine 9 May has taken on new significance.

title: 'There's power in names': Antigua unearths lost ancestors
description: A landmark genealogy project is unearthing the names of enslaved people whose stories were erased.

title: Wealthy Russians flee to Dubai to avoid sanctions
description: Property purchases by Russians in Dubai surged by 67% in the first quarter of 2022, a report says.

title: Myanmar civil war: ‘I saw my son’s body on Facebook’
description: After the Myanmar military entered his village, Joseph fled into the jungle but his 13-year-old was killed.

title: Africa's digital business: The women swapping shops for smartphones
description: Three African women explain how they have boosted their income by going digital since Covid.

title: Bill Gates on Elon Musk feud and Jeffrey Epstein meetings
description: The Microsoft tycoon talks to the BBC about divorce, conspiracy theories and Elon Musk.

title: Why Sigrid feels on top of the world
description: The pop star talks lockdown blues, singing Nirvana at school, and why she moved all her gold discs.

title: How Covid-scarred Shanghai will finally exit lockdown
description: A mass clean-up is sweeping through Shanghai, with the city's gradual reopening expected to follow.

title: Russia rehearses World War Two victory parade
description: Military vehicles, weapons and soldiers were on display at a rehearsal for Russia's Victory Day parade.

title: Dust storm and wildfires seen from space
description: Satellite images show gusts of up to 60mph blowing dust across Colorado and plumes of smoke in New Mexico.

title: Disabled children 'dumped' in Ukrainian institutions
description: Thousands of disabled Ukrainian children reportedly left in institutions that can’t care for them.

title: Durban floods survivors: 'I thought the world was ending'
description: Moeketsi Manake and his family talk about losing everything, including their house, in the Durban floods.

title: Hungary will veto EU oil ban proposal - minister
description: Zoltán Kovács says the proposal is against the country's interests and would ruin the Hungarian economy.

title: Ukraine: Putin 'apologizes' to Israeli PM over Russia's Holocaust remarks — live updates
description: Russia's President Vladimir Putin discussed the war in Ukraine with Israel's Prime Minister Naftali Bennett after his foreign minister infuriated Israel with comments about Hitler. Follow DW for the latest.

title: Champions League: Real Madrid, Karim Benzema and the greatest remontada of all
description: Karim Benzema was the hero once again as Real Madrid produced another stunning comeback to shock Manchester City and reach the Champions League final. Impossible, unthinkable, unimaginable – yet not for the first time.

title: RECOMMENDED — Western companies are leaving Russia, taking Russian jobs with them. DW spoke to people who are now unemployed.
description: More and more Russians are losing their jobs due to western sanctions on Russia, and some are having to painfully rethink their future. With some sanctions' effects yet to be felt, the number of unemployed could grow.

title: Habeck: LNG lawsuit hinders German efforts to move away from Russian energy
description: The Economy and Climate Minister says the legal action against the accelerated construction of an import terminal for liquefied natural gas will make it harder to move away from Russian energy.

title: Moldova: 'I'm worried about the children'
description: In villages close to the breakaway Moldovan region of Trans-Dniester, many residents fear they could be dragged into Russia's war on Ukraine. For some, the current events bring back painful memories of conflict.

title: WHO estimates nearly 15 million deaths linked to COVID pandemic
description: The World Health Organization said more than twice as many people died as a result of the COVID pandemic than official data shows, if including deaths of other causes that might not have occurred in more typical times.

title: Zelenskyy tells donor conference: 'Freedom must protect and provide'
description: Poland and Sweden hosted an international donors' conference to raise aid for Ukraine. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged donors to show that "freedom" protects better than "tyranny."

title: Why is India falling in the World Press Freedom Index?
description: India fell eight places in the World Press Freedom Index, down to 150 out of 180 countries. Critics say the ranking reflects increased pressure and violence against journalists.

title: Think 8 hours of sleep is best? Think again!
description: Are you 38 or older? Then you may want to rethink how much sleep you truly need. A team of international researchers has found that less is more.

title: Ukraine conflict: Steinmeier and Zelenskyy have 'good, constructive, important conversation'
description: The German president and Chancellor Olaf Scholz have both been invited to Kyiv, according to Frank-Walter Steinmeier's office. He had planned to go to Kyiv in April, but was told not to come on the eve of his trip.

title: 5 things we can learn from Marlene Dietrich
description: Marlene Dietrich died on May 6, 1992 — 30 years ago. She fled the Nazis and conquered Hollywood. She remains a role model in times of crisis.

title: Ukraine: How farm vehicles stolen by Russia were remotely disabled
description: Russian soldiers looted combine harvesters and tractors worth millions of dollars from Ukraine, according to a media report. But the machinery was deactivated remotely before it could be put to use.

title: Brittney Griner's Russian detention highlights WNBA's growing problem
description: The WNBA is seen as the world's best women's basketball league. However, the arrest of one of its biggest stars has highlighted problems involving time and money that are forcing players to go abroad in the off-season.

title: ECOWAS criticized over West African coups
description: The Economic Community of West African States has reacted to putsches in the region with appeals, sanctions or troop deployments. But criticism of the bloc's inconsistent actions is growing.

title: Can Indonesia and Germany build ties ahead of major summits?
description: Indonesia has been invited by Germany to attend the G7 summit in June, raising hopes of more bilateral cooperation amid a thorny geopolitical landscape.

title: EU threatens Vladimir Putin's Patriarch Kirill
description: Patriarch Kirill of Moscow is an ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin and shares his anti-Western views. That's made him a target of European Union sanctions.

title: Bank of England raises interest rates to 13-year-high
description: It is the fourth month in a row the central bank's Monetary Policy Committee has voted for a rise. Policymakers are currently trying to stem inflation amid high energy prices sparked partly by Russia's war in Ukraine.

title: Bitcoin boom spikes amid perceived risks
description: Central African Republic and El Salvador have made Bitcoin legal tender and Panama has approved a bill to regulate crypto assets. Experts warn that nations that adopt crypto currencies risk instability.

title: Documenta cancels talks amid antisemitism row
description: The 2022 edition of the world-famous contemporary art show has suddenly axed discussions on the topic of artistic freedom, which had planned to address accusations of antisemitism.

title: UK regional elections: Boris Johnson under scrutiny, historic vote in N. Ireland predicted
description: The British prime minister has faced calls to step down after breaking COVID lockdown rules. In Northern Ireland, polls suggest the Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein could win the largest number of seats.

title: New German open letter: 'Yes' to weapons for Ukraine
description: Pianist Igor Levit, Nobel laureate Herta Müller and 55 other intellectuals have sent an appeal to Chancellor Olaf Scholz. They say Germany should supply heavy weapons to Ukraine.

title: More than prayers: The faithful who aid Ukraine's front line
description: In western Ukraine, a religious community led by Greek-Catholic monks is supporting the war effort by providing clothes and medical supplies for soldiers on the front line.

title: China's COVID curbs rattle EU business confidence
description: More European businesses in China are looking to shift their investments due to the country's strict coronavirus lockdowns, according to the European Chamber of Commerce.

title: India: Policeman arrested for raping alleged child gang rape victim
description: Police in India arrested an officer accused of raping a 13-year-old girl who had gone to the police station to file a gang-rape case.

title: Germany plans documentation center on Nazi occupation in Europe
description: Almost 80 years after the end of the Second World War, the German government has approved a concept for a documentation center in Berlin. Its focus: the effects of the Nazi era in Europe.

title: What are millets and can they help create global food security?
description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has pushed food insecurity onto the table. Could an overlooked cereal help steady the situation and feed the global population in an era of climate crisis?

title: Germany: Woman sentenced for poking holes in partner's condoms
description: In what the judge described as a "historic" case, a woman has been found guilty of sexual assault after poking holes in her partner's condoms without his knowledge or consent.

title: 'Navalny' documentary hits theaters in Germany
description: Being an outspoken enemy of the Kremlin nearly cost Alexei Navalny his life. In this documentary that feels like a spy thriller, Putin's rival uncovers the facts about his poisoning.

title: Germany's Scholz: 'Western Balkans belong in Europe'
description: The leaders of Serbia and Kosovo met with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin. Leaders voiced optimism at the prospect of both joining the European Union.

title: Champions League: Jürgen Klopp's Liverpool to meet Real Madrid in 2018 re-run
description: Real Madrid will meet Liverpool in the Champions League final following Madrid's late turnaround against Manchester City. It's a repeat of the 2018 final, with Jürgen Klopp determined not to let history repeat itself.

title: Scholz stands firm on Ukraine visit amid criticism at home and abroad
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz addressed Ukraine's refusal to welcome President Frank-Walter Steinmeier again Wednesday, calling it "a problem for the German people." He said Kyiv needed to do its part to resolve the issue.

title: Ukraine: How drones are changing the way of war
description: The war in Ukraine shows that unmanned aerial vehicles are part of modern warfare. Drones have various tasks from aerial surveillance to missile defense.

title: German Overshoot Day: 'We cannot continue like this'
description: Germany has used more resources in the first third of 2022 than are sustainably available to it for an entire year. Here's what needs to change.

title: North Korea cracks down on 'capitalist' pop culture
description: Some North Koreans are defying strict fashion and style regulations to fight conformity. But their expressions of individualism could cost them their freedom.

title: DW documentary 'Guardians of Truth' premieres in Berlin
description: Turkish journalist Can Dündar and Mexican investigative journalist Anabel Hernandez both live in exile. They share their stories in a new documentary and at the Berlin premiere.

title: COVID: Omicron variants are 'escaping previous immunity'
description: You may be at risk of catching new COVID subvariants BA.4 or BA.5 even if you had the original omicron, as virologist Alex Sigal told DW's Science Unscripted.

title: Germany warns prices may spike as Russia sanctions tighten
description: Germany's Cabinet has wrapped two days and talks about the war in Ukraine and its impact on the German economy. The government warned that a planned EU oil embargo could cause supply problems and even higher inflation.

title: Ukrainian troops get training in Germany
description: Ukrainian soldiers are receiving weapons training on military bases in Germany. Legal advisers are discussing whether that makes Germany a party to war.

title: Open letter about weapons deliveries to Ukraine draws criticism
description: The publication of an open letter to German Chancellor Scholz signed by leading cultural figures has triggered a fierce debate about the planned delivery of heavy weapons to Ukraine — especially on social media.

title: Can Algeria contribute to the EU's energy security?
description: Timely decisions, long-term commitments and a broader vision could help the European Union increase ties with the Western Mediterranean. Algeria, with its large reserves, could enhance the bloc's energy security.

title: DOK.fest Munich puts spotlight on Ukraine
description: After a two-year break due to the pandemic, the documentary film festival is once again held in cinemas. A political thriller about Alexei Navalny opens the event.

title: Will buying cars online really take off?
description: Boosted by the popularity of electric automaker Tesla, more people than ever are buying vehicles online. UBS estimates the web will make up half of all car sales by 2030, but what will that mean for traditional dealers?

title: Breed accounts for less than 10% of a dog's behavior
description: If you're looking for a dog with a specific personality, its breed will tell you less than the environment in which it is raised, a new study suggests.

title: To be fire and flame: German expressions with 'fire'
description: May 4 marks International Firefighters' Day — a time to honor their work, while also learning some German expressions involving fire.

title: Will an EU oil embargo put the lights out at Schwedt's refinery?
description: As EU member states push for a Russian oil embargo, Germany's PCK Schwedt refinery is facing an uncertain future. It runs wholly on Russian imports, and many locals aren't so sure alternatives can be found in time.

title: Carbon farming: Climate change solution or greenwashing?
description: European agriculture produces millions of tons of CO2 every year. Could encouraging farmers to capture carbon on their land to sell credits to businesses help reduce emissions?

title: 'Zombie TV': The disintegration of Russia's free press
description: On World Press Freedom Day, a look at how Russia's media has evolved since the 1990s: 37 journalists have been murdered in Russia since Vladimir Putin took office in 2000.

title: DW documentary series 'Guardians of Truth' looks at press freedom
description: In this new DW documentary series, exiled Turkish journalist Can Dündar meets Mexican journalist Anabel Hernandez. Both have paid a high price for their fight for truth.

title: Bundesliga: Leverkusen jubilant as top-four race tilts away from RB Leipzig
description: Monday's doubleheader saw Leverkusen tighten their grip on a top four place in the Bundesliga. While Moussa Diaby and Patrik Schick shone for Leverkusen against Frankfurt, RB Leipzig crashed in Mönchengladbach.

title: Germans split over heavy weapons deliveries to Ukraine
description: The German public is divided on the issue of military support for Ukraine. Many fear the delivery of tanks and training of Ukrainian soldiers in Germany may drag the country into the war.

title: Is India facing a post-pandemic employment crisis?
description: India's job market is tightening, and skilled workers are finding it harder to enter the workforce. Government job drives and the informal economy have been unable to make up the difference.

title: What are the COVID entry rules for travelers to European countries?
description: Most European countries have lifted travel restrictions — despite ongoing high infection numbers. DW Travel has compiled this overview of EU rules.

title: Record-breaking heat waves show we need to adapt to the climate crisis now
description: India is just the latest country to face life-threatening temperatures before summer has even started. As extreme heat becomes more frequent around the world, how can affected areas adapt to remain livable?

title: COVID travel restrictions: Germany
description: Travel in Europe is subject to COVID-19 restrictions. The omicron variant has led to higher numbers of infections, which are often less severe. This is how Germany is responding to the current situation.

title: The story of Germany's national anthem
description: Created in the 19th century, the "Deutschlandlied" was sullied by the Nazis. Germany decided 70 years ago it would adopt only the third verse of the original song as its national anthem.

title: Pride in defeat, growing support and hope for the future for Wolfsburg's women
description: Wolfsburg lost on aggregate to Barcelona, but victory on the night and a clear philosophy off the field is earning them support — culminating in a record attendance on Saturday. The path forward for the club is clear.

title: Europe cooperates on gas, as Russia turns off taps to Poland and Bulgaria
description: Russia has halted gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria, ramping up the pressure on all EU states to find alternative suppliers. Some are working on cutting Russian gas altogether, others have plans to share with neighbors.

title: Russia posts trained dolphins at Black Sea naval base, satellite images show
description: Dolphin pens were moved to the Black Sea naval base around the time Russia invaded Ukraine, according to the US Naval Institute's analysis of satellite imagery.

title: Europa League: RB Leipzig one step closer to a second final — but would a trophy bring acceptance?
description: After victory over Rangers, RB Leipzig are one step closer to reaching their first-ever European final. The club hope a trophy might legitimize their place in German football, but are there some things money can't buy?

title: Origin of hepatitis outbreak in kids is still unknown
description: Doctors are puzzled by an unknown strain of hepatitis presenting in children, which has in some cases caused liver failure. But they are learning more. Symptoms are like jaundice.

title: Elvira Nabiullina: The central banker Vladimir Putin is relying on to clean up Russia's economic mess
description: Elvira Nabiullina has charmed many in the West with her policymaking — and clothing choices. Analysts say she has blemished her reputation by remaining at the helm to help sustain Putin's war machine in Ukraine.

title: About a million people live near dangerous dams in Brazil
description: Data analysis by DW reveals many Brazilians live near dams that, without proper maintenance and governmental oversight, could be deadly in the case of failure.

title: Eintracht Frankfurt show 'Europa League face' against West Ham in London
description: Frankfurt lead their Europa League semifinal following an absorbing first leg in London. The German club continue to show their best form in Europe as they beat West Ham to hold the advantage ahead of the return leg.

title: Cashing in: No payment problems for Russian tourists in Turkey
description: Turkey is trying to attract more Russian tourists by expanding the usage of the Russian Mir payment system in the country, as it seeks to bypass payment bottleneck created by Western sanctions.

title: Putin and Parkinson's: What experts say about his health
description: A video released by the Kremlin last weekend shows Putin in seemingly bad health. Some commentators and tabloids claim he has Parkinson's. What do doctors think?

title: Swiping right on climate love: Dating apps and environmental advocacy
description: Dating platforms have noticed their users are hot for climate issues and are incorporating features to help them connect with each other. But how useful are additions like OkCupid's climate advocate badge?

title: Germany top buyer of Russian energy since Ukraine invasion began: report
description: Russian fossil fuel exports are undermining sanctions imposed on the Kremlin over its invasion of Ukraine, a study says. Germany and the EU remain the biggest buyers of Russian energy.

title: Mars probe discovers 'shocking' new aurora
description: The Emirates Mars Mission says it's a first: They have spotted a worm-like aurora that stretches halfway round Mars. It looks like our northern lights.

title: Europe’s 'middle class' clubs battle to save Champions League
description: UEFA are proposing to increase the number of games in the Champions League and offer a safety net to its richest clubs. The plans have been derided as a Super League by the back door and some clubs are fighting back.

title: Turning the tide on land degradation
description: Human activity has led to widespread land degradation and put our very survival as a species at risk. But by reversing course, we can tackle climate change and biodiversity loss — and make a better life for billions.

title: Warsaw and Budapest split over Russian energy ties
description: Poland and Hungary have shared a tilt towards the nationalist right, bound also by a mutual distrust of the EU. But their relations with Russia are anything but alike. DW explores the energy ties that bind — and don't.

title: Elon Musk buys Twitter: What it means for the platform
description: Musk's vision of creating a bastion of free speech with less moderation and a higher bar for removing offending tweets could also lead to more abusive content, disinformation and hate speech, critics fear.

title: Endometriosis: The long wait for a diagnosis
description: Sabrina Lobing waited more than a decade for a diagnosis that explained her symptoms. Now she knows she has endometriosis — a disease that little is known about and yet is very common.

title: How Filip Kostic became the modern Bundesliga wingback
description: Eintracht Frankfurt are in the final four of the Europa League, and they couldn’t have done it without Kostic. It's not always been easy, but Jasmine Baba explains how the club got the best out of their Serbian winger.

title: Scientists sound alarm bells on noise pollution
description: The rumble of road traffic and trains, the bustle of the bar downstairs or the roar of a plane taking off – noise is a problem that is increasingly hurting health and disrupting ecosystems.

title: Afghan women athletes: prisoners in their own homes
description: It's eight months since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan and the country has slipped down the news agenda. 'The world forgets about us,' says Friba Rezayee, the first Afghan woman to compete at the Olympics.

title: RECOMMENDED — What does a US cryptocurrency firm want from a lower-tier UK football club?
description: Crawley Town have become the first professional football club to be bought by a cryptocurrency firm. The new owners promise to "shake up the status quo" and recruit global fans with NFTs. Is this new dawn what it seems?

title: Beyond ecology: The trees at the heart of our culture
description: From Ireland to the Amazon to Kenya, trees can hold traditional or even sacred value. DW takes a look at trees and forests of cultural importance to communities around the world. Some are under threat.

title: Opinion: Bayern Munich's 10th title - joy or relief?
description: Bayern Munich have won their 10th straight Bundesliga title, sparking renewed conversation about the competitive issues at the top of German football. Perhaps the biggest concern though, is the question of fun.

title: Bundesliga: Bayern Munich's 10th title prompts celebration — but also concern
description: Ten league titles in a row should be cause for celebration, one might think. But Bayern Munich's latest triumph is accompanied by acute concern, both in Munich and further afield.

title: EU reaches deal on major law aiming to regulate tech giants
description: As per the Digital Services Act (DSA), tech giants such as Facebook and Google will be expected to moderate illegal content on their platforms. It's the second part of the bloc's project seeking to rein in tech giants.

title: Shanghai COVID lockdown threatens new export delays
description: Nearly a third of goods leaving the Port of Shanghai are held up due to a strict COVID lockdown. The delays are set to exacerbate a supply chain crisis that has caused shortages and price rises across the world.

title: Let's talk about salt — how unhealthy is it really?
description: Most people consume too much salt — with potentially massive effects for their health. But it's possible to find a healthy balance.

title: So you want to live forever?
description: Spoiler: You probably won't be able to live forever, even if you want to. How about settling for a life free from age-related ailments like Alzheimer's or arthritis instead?

title: COVID: In a crowd of unmasked people, can a mask still protect you?
description: Many countries around the world are easing mask mandates. If no one else is masking up, should you?

title: From Mumbai to Paris, the cities investing in the planet
description: This Earth Day, we show how city councils and mayors have stepped up to boldly decarbonize in the face of national government inaction.

title: Energy crisis: What role can Germany's oil and gas sector play?
description: As Germany looks to ditch Russian oil and gas for good, its domestic energy industry is a key side actor — but can it step up to the plate? We search for clues in the village where Germany's oil sector was born.

title: Climate crisis: How to cope with eco-anxiety
description: Does worrying about climate change keep you up at night? Growing numbers of people are struggling with eco-anxiety, or distress about the state of the planet. If you're one of them, these expert tips might help.

title: Glass windows kill billions of birds a year. Scientists are working to change that
description: Conservationists are trying to convince governments and building owners around the world to introduce changes to stop birds from flying into reflective glass. Experts say the solutions are surprisingly simple.

title: The thriving gardens at the heart of Rio de Janeiro's favelas
description: In one of the most dangerous and deprived neighborhoods in the Brazilian city, residents are now finding hope and employment by growing fruit and vegetables.

title: European Space Agency halts cooperation with Russia on moon missions
description: The European Space Agency's move marks the latest in the deterioration of space-based relations with Russia.

title: New omicron variants: What we know so far
description: A new omicron subvariant, BA.2.12.1, is spreading in the US and India. German Health Minister Lauterbach has expressed concern about the highly contagious coronavirus variant. Here's what we know so far.

title: China turns cities into sponges to stop flooding
description: In the coming decade, China is expanding its plans for sponge cities. They can help prevent flooding, promote biodiversity and cut emissions. But what exactly are these cities and how do they work?

title: Germany: Over 1 in 4 people have 'migrant background'
description: The number of people with "migrant background" — foreigners and people with foreign roots — keeps rising in Germany, with Turkey, Poland and Russia the top three countries of familial origin.

title: Cities are major polluters: Can we make them climate neutral?
description: Spewing most of the world's heat-trapping gases, fast-growing cities need to be transformed into clean, low emissions ecosystems in the struggle against climate breakdown.

title: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti: ISS is a 'beacon of hope'
description: Ahead of the launch of her Minerva mission to the International Space Station, Cristoforetti talked about the cooperation among European, US and Russian crew members in light of the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine.

title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Presses on Eastern Front and Targets Final Fighters in Mariupol
description: Russian forces sought to destroy the last pocket of resistance at Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, which would let President Vladimir V. Putin claim a major victory before Moscow’s military celebration on Monday.

title: India Finds Russian Oil an Irresistible Deal, No Matter the Diplomatic Pressure
description: A parade of emissaries have urged a harder line on Russia. But India’s political neutrality over the war in Ukraine has expanded into economic opportunism.

title: Elon Musk Left a South Africa That Was Rife With Misinformation and White Privilege
description: The apartheid era created all-white enclaves littered with anti-Black government propaganda and sheltered from the atrocities of apartheid.

title: In Senegal’s Former Capital, a Colonial Statue in Hiding Is No Longer Welcome
description: The city of Saint-Louis was shaped by Louis Faidherbe, a French governor who also led brutal military campaigns in West Africa. What to do with his legacy has divided Senegal.

title: U.K. Local Elections Guide: What to Look For
description: National politics may not be front and center in voters’ minds, but how they cast their ballots could signal their opinions of the main parties.

title: Anti-Putin Russians Are Leaving, With a Push From the Kremlin
description: Many Russians who are designated “foreign agents” by the government view it as another form of repression that makes living in the country, or returning to it, untenable.

title: Nicaragua’s Secretive Ruling Family Reaches Out Quietly to the U.S.
description: Sanctions intended to thwart the president’s dictatorial actions have hit his family and inner circle hard. More pain is expected as sanctions hit Russia, an ally.

title: Iraqis Choke Under a Blanket of Dust as Sandstorms Sweep the Country
description: Orange skies signaled yet another dusty day for millions of Iraqis. It was the seventh such storm in recent months, and experts say more are on the way.

title: What Is Russia’s May 9 Victory Day, and What Might Putin Say?
description: In the two decades that Vladimir V. Putin has led Russia, the country’s Victory Day marches, honoring Soviet sacrifices of World War II, have transformed into huge military spectacles and nostalgic celebrations.

title: Why Boris Johnson Will Be Tested in UK by Local Elections
description: The British prime minister is under fire for lockdown-breaking parties. But many voters are skeptical that the opposition can solve issues such as soaring prices.

title: In Mexico, One Cartel Is Cleared, but Others Storm In
description: In the state of Michoacán, small drug cartels compete with larger ones for territory, leaving the residents caught in the middle of a brutal turf war.

title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Leave Millions Out of Work
description: Migrant workers and recent college graduates have been hit hardest by shuttered factories, closed construction sites and an anemic job market.

title: China’s Covid Policies Have European Companies Wary of Investing
description: Lockdowns and supply chain issues have soured European businesses in China on the idea of further investment in the country, a survey finds.

title: Turkey’s Plan to Draw Refugees Back to Syria: Homes for 1 Million
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will build homes, schools, hospitals and more in northern Syria, but experts question whether refugees will return willingly.

title: Ricardo Alarcon, Diplomat and Castro Confidant, Dies at 84
description: As Havana’s go-between with the U.S., he negotiated Elián González’s return to Cuba. He was also the country’s U.N. representative on two occasions.

title: Why the Battle for Mariupol Is Important for Putin
description: A victory in the predominantly Russian-speaking city could give a veneer of credibility to the Russian leader’s false claims of ridding Ukraine of “Nazis.”

title: Europe’s Quest to Replace Russian Gas Faces Plenty of Hurdles
description: Climate concerns, investor reticence and political disputes complicate a shift to supplies from the United States, North Africa and the Mediterranean.

title: They Thought the Skulls Were Murder Victims’. They Were Off by Centuries.
description: Originally thought to be the remnants of gang killings, dozens of skulls found in a cave in southern Mexico are now believed to be from sacrificial killings more than 1,000 years ago.

title: This Trump Play in London Is a Comedy. Unless You’re American.
description: Mike Bartlett’s “The 47th” presents political turmoil in the United States for laughs. But some find it more like a horror story.

title: Death Toll During Pandemic Far Exceeds Totals Reported by Countries, W.H.O. Says
description: Nearly 15 million more people died during the first two years of the pandemic than would have been expected during normal times, the organization found. The previous count of virus deaths, from countries’ reporting, was six million.

title: ‘Not Good for Learning’
description: New research is showing the high costs of long school closures in some communities.

title: Searching for What Connects Us, Carlo Rovelli Explores Beyond Physics
description: The physicist ranges widely — from black holes to Buddhism to climate change — in his new book, “There Are Places in the World Where Rules Are Less Important Than Kindness.”

title: Why Climate Change Makes It Harder to Fight Fire With Fire
description: Worsening wildfires in recent years have led officials to embrace planned fires to thin forests before disaster strikes. But the warming world is making it tougher to do safely.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A planned embargo on Russian oil.

title: Stanislav Shushkevich, First Leader of Post-Soviet Belarus, Dies at 87
description: He helped formalize the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, led his country until 1994, then became a vocal critic of his successor, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

title: Putin Could Use Russia’s Victory Day to Expand Ukraine War, Some Fear
description: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.

title: Moderna Reaps $5.9 Billion From Its Vaccine Sales
description: Stéphane Bancel, the company’s chief executive officer, said Moderna has $21 billion worth of advance purchase agreements for the vaccine.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Ban on Russian Oil?
description: The E.U. proposed a total embargo.

title: NOAA Image Catches Wildfire Smoke and Dust on Collision Course
description: A time-lapse image of smoke from wildfires in New Mexico and dust from a storm in Colorado illustrates the scope of Western catastrophe.

title: European Union Takes a Leap With a Russian Oil Embargo
description: The ban, once seen as unlikely, is a significant tightening of the squeeze on Russia’s economy, and a financial blow to Europe, too.

title: Putin-Linked Superyacht May Elude Sanctions, by Setting Sail
description: The Italian police are in a race to finish investigating a $700 million vessel thought to be the Russian president’s — before it’s out of their reach.

title: John Doerr Gives Stanford $1.1 Billion for Climate School
description: The billionaire venture capitalist said the study of climate change and sustainability would be the “new computer science.”

title: In Pakistan, Violence by Baluch Separatists Destabilizes Region
description: A government plagued by volatility is trying to quell a separatist movement in Baluchistan while also fighting other insurgencies and striving for economic development.

title: Saving Ukrainian Art, and Helping Artists, One NFT at a Time
description: Lika Spivakovska, the owner of two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, has partnered with an NFT gallery in Puerto Rico to auction off pictures of art damaged and created during the war. The money will go to Ukrainian artists and other humanitarian aid.

title: Roe Inspired Activists Worldwide, Who May Be Rethinking Strategy
description: Feminist movements in some countries similarly sought abortion protections in their courts, but for others, the goal was legislative change.

title: A Trump Win in Ohio
description: We look at last night’s election results.

title: A Crumbling Russian ‘Spyville’ Returns to Polish Hands
description: A Warsaw housing complex built in the 1970s and rented by Russia was reputed to be a nest of spies. The city’s government has seized the site and pledged to hand it over to the Ukrainian community.

title: Japan Says It Needs Nuclear Power. Can Host Towns Ever Trust It Again?
description: The Ukraine war has shown the fragility of Japan’s energy supplies. But the decision to restart plants after the Fukushima disaster is fraught with emotions and political calculation.

title: Covid and Omicron Variants: Lessons From Gamma, Iota and Mu
description: Studying the coronavirus variants that have faded away could help us prepare for what comes next, scientists say.

title: E.U. to Propose Total Ban on Russian Oil Imports
description: The  proposal will be presented in detail to E.U. ambassadors Wednesday and is expected to be adopted by the end of the week.

title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile Ahead of Yoon’s Inauguration
description: Kim Jong-un has sought to improve the North’s nuclear capabilities and gain diplomatic leverage with Washington and the incoming administration of Yoon Suk-yeol.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Shockwaves from a Supreme Court leak.

title: Handful of Virus Cases Emerge After White House Correspondents’ Dinner
description: Cases are not uncommon in Washington these days, and there is no certainty that those who tested positive were infected at the dinner.

title: Sensing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
description: ‘You have exploded the myth of Putin’s invincibility,’ Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers, one of several Western sources of cheerleading on Tuesday.

title: Britain’s Parliament Is Rocked by Sexist Episodes. Again.
description: Encouraging more women to run for office, critics say, is just one way to counter pervasive misogyny and sexual harassment in Parliament.

title: Russian Missiles Hit Power Stations in Lviv and Along Crucial Railways
description: Altogether, six electrical substations were struck along the railways in central and western Ukraine, according to a top rail official. The rail system is the country’s lifeline for humanitarian and military supplies.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The End of Roe?
description: Abortion is in jeopardy in the U.S.

title: Beijing Tightens Measures as Some Residents Grow Weary
description: Authorities are trying to avoid a full-scale lockdown in the Chinese capital like the one imposed in Shanghai.

title: 6 Podcasts That Go Deeper on the Headlines
description: These series, on subjects like the war in Ukraine, the storming of the U.S. Capitol and the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, can help combat news fatigue.

title: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
description: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.

title: Evacuees From Azovstal Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
description: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.

title: Smithsonian Adopts Policy on Ethical Returns in a Nod to Changing Norms
description: The institution’s leaders hope other cultural centers will follow its lead. It has already announced plans to return most of its collection of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria under the new policy.

title: Boris Johnson Calls Russia War ‘Ukraine’s Finest Hour’
description: In the first address by a foreign leader to Ukraine’s Parliament, Britain’s prime minister burnished his credentials as a supporter of the resistance to Russia.

title: Roe, on the Edge
description: Roe v. Wade seems to be on the cusp of falling.

title: What Sanctions Have Been Imposed on Russia?
description: Our reporters answer readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you asked about economic penalties and how Putin could respond.

title: Israel Plans Zip Line for Ancient Jerusalem
description: A Jewish settler group is promoting projects that opponents say will change the delicate historic, religious and political balance in highly symbolic areas around Jerusalem’s Old City.

title: Cuban Migrants Arrive to U.S. in Record Numbers, on Foot, Not by Boat
description: Political repression and escalating economic difficulties on the island, along with a new visa-free travel policy in Nicaragua, are some of the factors driving the change.
